title: Carbon Sequestration in Timber
text:
To avoid catastrophic climate change, not only do we need to curb emissions, we’ll also probably have to pull a bunch of C02 out of the air. How much? A 2017 study estimated that we’ll need to sequester ~200 billion tons of C02 by 2050 1. That’s about the weight of two million aircraft carriers.
Trees seem to be pretty good at sequestering carbon. In fact, a recent study suggested that the IPCC goal of reforesting 1 billion hectares would result in ~205 billion tons of carbon sequestered 2. Perfect! Unless… we don’t end up reforesting those 1 billion ha after all. From a cursory google search, it sounds like the global market for wood products is expected to grow by 1/3 to $900 billion by 2026 3. And we’re gonna need a lot more food by 2050…




Footnotes


Mac Dowell, N., Fennell, P., Shah, N. et al. The role of CO2 capture and utilization in mitigating climate change. Nature Clim Change 7, 243–249 (2017). https://doi.org/10.1038/nclimate3231↩︎
Jean-Francois Bastin, Yelena Finegold, Claude Garcia, Danilo Mollicone, Marcelo Rezende, Devin Routh, Constantin M. Zohner and Thomas W. Crowther. The global tree restoration potential. Science 365 (6448), 76-79. DOI: 10.1126/science.aax0848↩︎
https://www.reportlinker.com/p06251038/Wood-Products-Global-Market-Report.html?utm_source=GNW↩︎
